text:
- I've been with AWS for
the last almost five years.
I'm part of the S3 metering team.

So we count and we measure how
much customers are using S3,
so we can build them correctly.
(upbeat music)

I was working as software
developer engineer
before in Spain.

At that time I was doing
some trainings about AWS,

and you could hear about AWS
everywhere on the internet,
when I saw that,

that must be like a really
interesting area to work on.
And yeah, basically I thought, "Why not?"

Something that was
really interesting for me
was the scope of AWS, right?

Like the amount of customers
that they are using AWS.
I was actually surprised at the beginning

because I thought that
would be like a big company,

probably making things happen
would be really complicated,
but I actually found out
that it wasn't that complicated, right?
Like the mindset of having small teams,
and the ownership that you have,
that gives you a lot of freedom.

Working at AWS, all those tiny
products are like startups,

that they have their
own designated roadmaps

and they actually work together
with the same vision, right?
That is basically having a very, very good
customer experience

and being the most customer-centric
company in the world.
And the fact that we have so much freedom,
and so much ownership on the things we do,
that gives you a feeling
that what you are doing means something.
(quiet upbeat music)
